section.name: Serializing and De-serializing Cache Objects
section.p: When using auxiliary caches, cache elements need to be serialized into a byte stream in order to be stored on disk or transported through a network. For reading from these caches, bytes must be de-serialized into objects. By default, JCS uses the standard JDK methods for serializing and de-serializing objects. However, all of the auxiliaries also support setting a custom serializer to have finer control of the behavior.
This document describes the built-in serializers and their configuration.

section.name: Standard Serializer
section.p: The StandardSerializer uses the JDK default serialization methods. Key and value classes must be Serializable for this to work.

De-serialization of objects out of untrusted data is a common source for vulnerabilities in code. JCS implements an ObjectInputFilter to address this problem. The filter for classes and packages allowed for de-serialization can be configured with a system property:
The syntax for the filter expression is documented in the JavaDoc of java.io.ObjectInputFilter.Config#createFilter.

section.name: Compressing Serializer
section.p: The CompressingSerializer gzips the bytes after serializing the cache object the default way. For reading, the bytes will be de-compressed first and then de-serialized into a Java object. The class can also be used as a wrapper around an arbitrary class implementing IElementSerializer.

section.name: Encrypting Serializer
section.p: The EncryptingSerializer uses AES to encrypt the bytes after serializing the cache object the default way. For reading, the bytes will be decrypted first and then de-serialized into a Java object. The class can also be used as a wrapper around an arbitrary class implementing IElementSerializer.

The implementation uses a symmetrical pre-shared key phrase for encrypting and decrypting the data. The key is salted separately for each object and the salt is stored together with the serialized data.

The encryption code uses the default constructor of SecureRandom() to create a random number generator. Depending on your security requirements, you should configure a SecureRandom that works for your environment, giving preference to the ones with good randomness (given that your environment generates entropy fast enough, we saw problems with Linux).

section.name: JSON Serializer
section.p: The JSONSerializer serializes the cache object to a UTF-8-encoded JSON string. The Java class name information for de-serialization is preserved in a separate className field. This serializer can be used to exchange data between different platforms or when text representations are required.
